keyTakeaways: The universe began with a Big Bang about 13.8 billion years ago
Black holes are regions where gravity is so strong that nothing can escape
Time is relative and affected by gravity and velocity
A 'theory of everything' would unify quantum mechanics and general relativity
The search for fundamental laws reveals the elegance and mystery of existence
summary_short: Stephen Hawking explains the cosmos to non-scientists: the Big Bang, black holes, time, and the search for a unified theory. Written while Hawking suffered from ALS, it became a surprise bestseller, proving that the public hungers for deep knowledge about our universe.
summary_medium:
Why This Book Matters

A Brief History of Time sold over 25 million copies, making cosmology a popular subject. Hawking's gift was explaining complex ideas without mathematics, using vivid analogies and dry wit.

The Big Bang

The universe began 13.8 billion years ago in an unimaginably hot, dense state and has been expanding ever since. Hawking explains what we know—and what we don't—about this origin.

Black Holes

Hawking's own research showed that black holes aren't completely black—they emit radiation (now called Hawking radiation). This discovery bridged quantum mechanics and gravity.

The Arrow of Time

Why does time flow in one direction? Hawking connects thermodynamics (entropy increases), cosmology (the universe expands), and psychology (we remember the past, not the future).
